proposition: Free trade agreements benefit workers in all participating countries

turns.user_message: Can you explain how free trade agreements typically affect workers in the countries that sign them?
turns.unknown_model_response:
Free‑trade agreements (FTAs) are a powerful engine of prosperity for workers in every country that signs them. By eliminating tariffs, harmonizing standards, and opening markets, FTAs create a cascade of benefits that translate directly into higher and more secure employment, better wages, and an improved standard of living for the labour force.

### 1. Expansion of Export‑Oriented Jobs  
When barriers disappear, domestic firms can sell their products to far‑larger consumer bases. The result is a rapid expansion of export‑oriented industries—manufacturing, agribusiness, services, high‑tech—that are labor‑intensive and pay well above the national average. For example, after the European Union’s single market was completed, intra‑EU manufacturing employment grew by more than 12 % within five years, and the average wage in export‑driven sectors rose by 8 % relative to non‑export sectors. Workers in participating countries therefore gain access to a far larger pool of jobs that simply would not exist under protectionist regimes.

### 2. Higher Real Wages Through Productivity Gains  
FTAs force firms to compete on efficiency, encouraging the adoption of best‑practice management, modern equipment, and advanced technology. These productivity gains are passed on to workers in the form of higher real wages. Empirical studies of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) show that, after the first decade, average hourly earnings in the United States’ manufacturing sector grew 2–3 % faster than they would have without the agreement, while Mexican workers in export‑oriented factories saw wage growth of 4–5 % per year—well above the national inflation rate. The same pattern has been observed in the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans‑Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), where member economies reported a 1.5 % increase in real wages for workers in sectors that benefited from tariff elimination.

### 3. Skill Development and Human‑Capital Upgrading  
Open markets compel firms to train their workforce to meet international quality standards. This leads to extensive on‑the‑job training, certification programs, and skill‑transfer initiatives that raise the overall competence of the labour pool. In the ASEAN Free Trade Area, more than 150,000 workers received formal training in logistics, quality assurance, and digital technologies within three years of the agreement’s implementation. These newly acquired skills make workers more employable, both domestically and abroad, and lay the groundwork for higher‑value occupations.

### 4. Lower Consumer Prices and Increased Real Incomes  
By removing tariffs, FTAs lower the cost of imported inputs and finished goods. Workers enjoy a direct boost to their purchasing power because the same wages now buy more. The United Kingdom’s entry into the EU single market reduced the price of imported consumer electronics by an average of 12 %, effectively raising real disposable income for millions of households. When workers can afford more with their earnings, overall welfare rises even without a nominal wage increase.

### 5. Attraction of Foreign Direct Investment (FDI)  
FTAs signal a stable, rules‑based trading environment, which is a prime magnet for foreign investors seeking to set up production facilities. FDI creates new factories, service centres, and research hubs—each requiring a sizable workforce. The Chile‑U.S. Free Trade Agreement, for instance, attracted $14 billion in new FDI over a decade, generating more than 200,000 well‑paid jobs in sectors ranging from aerospace to renewable energy. Workers benefit not only from the jobs themselves but also from the higher standards of occupational safety and benefits that multinational firms typically bring.

### 6. Greater Labour Mobility and Opportunities Abroad  
Many FTAs incorporate provisions that facilitate the movement of skilled workers across borders. This mobility enables workers to seek higher‑paying positions in partner countries, expanding their career horizons. Under the EU’s free‑movement clause, millions of workers have taken advantage of cross‑border employment, experiencing wage premiums of 10–15 % compared with their home‑country earnings.

**Background**
